headline: Fed Signal Could Revive a Problem for China’s Central Bank
summary: The Fed could revive a pesky problem for China’s central bank Wednesday, if officials signal they are ready to lift rates more than the three times they currently project for 2017.

headline: Populism Suffers Setback in Australian Vote
summary: The global rise of nationalist politics hit a hurdle in the heart of Australia’s mining belt, as an anti-immigrant party won fewer votes than expected in state elections, contributing to a crushing loss for the government.

headline: After Record Year for Fatal Overdoses, New York City Targets Opioids
summary: New York City will spend $38 million annually to combat an opioid epidemic that killed more than 1,000 New Yorkers last year, city officials said Monday.

headline: Okta and Yext File for IPOs After Snap’s Debut
summary: Okta and Yext, two software startups, are trying to pick up where Snap Inc. left off, becoming the first tech companies to file for an initial public offering since the parent of Snapchat’s blockbuster IPO earlier this month

headline: Rising ‘Real’ Yields Signal Optimism on Economy
summary: Inflation-adjusted bond yields are rising again, reflecting investors’ confidence in the global expansion and likely giving the Fed latitude to raise short-term interest rates repeatedly this year.

headline: De Blasio Declares State of Emergency Starting at Midnight
summary: With a major storm bearing down on New York City, Mayor Bill de Blasio Monday announced a state of emergency and urged New Yorkers to stay off the roads.

headline: UPS Gives Top Brass a Raise Despite Missed Targets
summary: United Parcel Service Chief Executive David Abney’s compensation rose 21% even as the parcel carrier missed many of its performance targets.

headline: Tillerson Used Email Alias at Exxon to Discuss Climate Change, N.Y. Says
summary: The state attorney general’s office says Exxon Mobil withheld documents in a probe into what it told investors about climate change, and that then-CEO Rex Tillerson used the name “Wayne Tracker” in discussions about the issue.

headline: Why Apple and Pfizer Are Piling Into Taiwan’s Bond Market
summary: A feature of the Taiwanese bond market makes it easy and relatively cheap for companies to redeem any debt they issue there before its due date—but that may be changing.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for edition of March 14, 2017.

headline: White House Back-Pedals on Claim Obama Wiretapped Trump’s Phones
summary: White House press secretary Sean Spicer on Monday back-pedaled on President Donald Trump’s claims that his phone line was ordered tapped by then-President Barack Obama, an allegation of illegality that Mr. Trump recently made on Twitter without providing any evidence.

headline: Egypt’s Ousted Leader Hosni Mubarak Is Ordered to Be Released
summary: Former Egyptian PresidentHosni Mubarak was ordered to be freed from detention on Monday, according to the prosecutor who signed his release order.

headline: Arrests at Ferguson Protest Fueled by Documentary’s Claims
summary: Three people were arrested in Ferguson, Mo., during a small protest that broke out after a documentary offered new details about the hours before a local police officer killed Michael Brown in 2014, police said.

headline: Farewell to Running’s Great Gandalf
summary: Beloved master’s marathoner Ed Whitlock dies at 86—first 70-something to run a sub three-hour marathon; ran 3:54 in October at age 85.

headline: New Jersey Lawmakers Vote to Raise Marriage Age to 18
summary: New Jersey lawmakers voted Monday to approve a bill that would ban marriage or civil unions for all people under the age of 18, even with parental consent.

headline: Waning Sales Force Layoffs by Gun Maker in New York
summary: Remington has laid off more than 120 workers at an upstate New York factory in response to falling demand for firearms, dealing a blow to an upstate village of 8,000.

headline: More Bank Capital Could Kill the Economy
summary: Regulators sparked the Great Recession with a credit crunch. Now they want to do it again.

headline: Seema Verma Confirmed as Head of Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
summary: Seema Verma, President Donald Trump’s pick to oversee the Medicare and Medicaid programs, won Senate confirmation in a largely party-line vote Monday, placing an advocate of overhauling Medicaid at the program’s helm.

headline: Deep States and Demagogues
summary: Sean Hannity reminds us that the paranoid style in politics is alive and well today.

headline: Make Blue States Great Again
summary: How a Trump presidency may help progressives embrace federalism.

headline: The Dutch Find Welfare and Immigration Make an Uneasy Mix
summary: Did my countrymen really turn into xenophobes and racists? No, they are as open-minded as ever.

headline: On ‘Right to Try,’ the FDA Should Proceed With Caution
summary: More access to unapproved drugs could be good policy, but there are risks even to terminal patients.

headline: Gee, Our Old LaSalle Looked Great
summary: Consumers now list exterior styling as the top reason for selecting a certain car model, thanks to Harley Earl.

headline: Bomb Threats Reshape Jewish Centers
summary: Since the start of the year, more than 100 threats have been made against dozens of Jewish community centers, schools and synagogues across the U.S. No bombs have been found, but the threats have reshaped life at these institutions.

headline: Thomas Vartanian In Running to Be Fed Vice Chair for Supervision
summary: A lawyer who has represented shareholders and financial firms in lawsuits against the government is under consideration for a top financial regulatory post at the Federal Reserve, according to two people familiar with the matter.

headline: Scotland to Seek Second Independence Referendum
summary: Scotland’s First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said she plans to seek approval to hold a second referendum on Scottish independence before the U.K. exits the European Union, expected in early 2019.

headline: Ex-Penn State Officials Plead Guilty in Sandusky Case
summary: Two former Pennsylvania State University officials pleaded guilty to misdemeanor child-endangerment charges, a week before they were set to go to trial over how they handled sex-abuse allegations against then-assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky.

headline: U.K. Firms Prepare for Post-Brexit World Even Before Talks Begin
summary: Many U.K. companies are taking action to prepare for life after Brexit even if no one quite knows how Britain’s departure from the European Union will affect business.

headline: Panel to Examine Consumer Bankruptcy and Student Loan Debt
summary: The federal bankruptcy law’s failure to help heavily indebted borrowers of student loans will be studied by a new panel of law professors, federal judges and consumer advocates.

headline: Arnold Palmer’s Legacy Honored in Mastercard Commercial
summary: Mastercard has unveiled a new ad, just in time for the Arnold Palmer Invitational, that shows how valuable a golf legend can be, even after his death.

headline: Buyout Firm Buys $800 Million of Assets From Itself
summary: Novel deal aims to extend period for which firm can hold assets, responding to competition from sovereign- wealth funds and other long-term investors.

headline: Why Health-Care Hurdles in Washington Will Cheer Wall Street
summary: Republicans’ Obamacare replacement faces trouble after a Congressional Budget Office report. That should please investors.

headline: Puerto Rico Board Approves Fiscal Road Map
summary: The federal board overseeing Puerto Rico’s finances approved a fiscal plan Monday that will serve as the foundation for negotiations with creditors over the U.S. territory’s $70 billion debt load.

headline: Trump Orders Cabinet to Streamline Agencies, Cut Waste
summary: Declaring his contingent of federal agency heads “one of the greatest cabinets in history,” President Donald Trump signed an executive order that directs his team to find ways to make their departments more efficient and effective.

headline: U.S. Treasury Secretary to Push G-20 on Currency Vows, Trade Policies
summary: U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin will push the world’s top economies to abide by existing exchange-rate agreements and promote “open and fair” trade at a coming meeting of finance chiefs this week, a senior Trump administration official said Monday.

headline: At White House, Patients Share Complaints About Obamacare
summary: When he was pitching his health-care overhaul, then-President Barack Obama highlighted the law’s winners. Now, in trying to undo that law, President Donald Trump is giving a platform to the law’s losers.

headline: New York Educators Eliminate Teacher-Certification Exam
summary: The New York Board of Regents scrapped a literacy test for public-school teacher certification, after a task force determined it was poorly designed and redundant. But the exam’s supporters warned of lowering standards.

headline: Former Obama Housing Official Raphael Bostic to Lead Atlanta Fed
summary: Raphael Bostic, a former Obama administration housing official, was named president of the Atlanta Fed, becoming the first African-American selected to lead one of the 12 regional Fed banks in the institution’s century of existence.

headline: ‘Paradise’ by Anohni Review: Still Provocative, Still Confrontational
summary: On her latest album, the singer addresses the destruction of the planet through hypocrisy, greed and disregard for higher values

headline: Intel Joins a Crowded Race for Self-Driving Cars
summary: Intel is the latest company racing to shape the future of autonomous transportation, joining traditional car makers, parts manufacturers and technology companies.

headline: Dollar Wavers Ahead of Busy Week
summary: The dollar wavered Monday as investors remained cautious ahead of central bank meetings and political events this week.

headline: Omens of Higher Wages
summary: The Fed is clearly behind the labor market curve in tightening.

headline: The Teams You Should Pick to Pull Off NCAA Tournament Upsets

headline: Intel’s Leap of Faith in Driverless Cars
summary: Buying Mobileye at a high valuation is risky, but Intel can’t afford to miss another growth market.

headline: Inflation: The Price Is Finally Right for the Fed
summary: Rising inflation expectations bode well for the central bank ahead of this week’s policy meeting.

headline: Trump, China’s Xi Planning to Meet Soon

headline: 5 Things on the Merkel-Trump Meeting
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel sets off for Washington on Monday night for her first meeting with President Donald Trump. Here are five things to watch as the two Western allies sit down later this week.

summary: Natural gas prices rose for the fourth session in a row on Monday, as cold weather forecasts pointed to increased demand before the end of winter.

headline: Metals: Weaker Dollar and Mine Strikes Lift Copper
summary: Copper prices closed at a one-week high Monday as the dollar weakened and traders refocused on supply disruptions at mines in Chile and Indonesia.

summary: Facebook said data about users cannot be used for surveillance, cracking down on a method police departments allegedly used to track protesters and activists.

headline: Study Suggests High-Spending Doctors Could Do Less Without Harming Patients
summary: U.S. Medicare patients whose doctors spent more on tests, scans and consultations were as likely to die within a month of leaving the hospital as patients with more parsimonious physicians, new research shows.

headline: NATO Chief Says Allies Still Fall Short of Fair Sharing of Defense Burden

headline: Dartmouth College Appoints Alice Ruth as New Endowment Chief

headline: Treasured American Values Are Slipping Away
summary: The fact that 83% of last year’s science competition finalists were the children of immigrants points more to the collapse of America’s education culture than the skills of immigrants’ children.

headline: Middlebury’s Principles Require Discipline
summary: Nowhere among the platitudes listed do the professors call for the rule of law.

summary: People are unprepared, unable or unwilling to do proper training, while precious time is wasted on kindergarten-like sessions called “Green Dot.”

headline: Does Recess Need Coaching?

summary: An expert on the Paris food scene sells her ‘cooking studio,’ which she uses to teach classes and write cookbooks

headline: Vista Equity Adds Canadian FinTech Firm DH to Portfolio

headline: Hedge-Fund Loses Big on Oil Bets

summary: NCR Corp. said Monday that it entered an agreement with Blackstone Group LP to allow the private-equity firm to sell off nearly half of its common stock and a portion of its preferred stock in the ATM maker.

summary: Launched by OK Cupid’s Sam Yagan, Corazon Capital specializes in seed-stage deals in the Midwest and has just closed its second fund at $40 million

summary: SunEdison has reached settlements with TerraForm Power and TerraForm Global that are worth $800 million in value to creditors waiting to be paid from its bankruptcy case.

summary: Oil-field services company John Wood will acquire rival Amec Foster Wheeler in a $2.73 billion all-share deal, the latest sign of consolidation in an industry hurt by weak oil prices.

summary: Malaysian police arrested seven people—five Filipinos and two Malaysians, including an immigration officer—over suspected links to Islamic State.

summary: William Ackman’s Pershing Square sold its stake in struggling drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals, taking a roughly $4 billion loss and bringing to a close one of the most tortured sagas in hedge-fund history.

headline: CBO Sees 24 Million More Uninsured, $337 Billion Deficit Cut With GOP Plan
summary: The number of Americans without health insurance would grow by 24 million under a House Republican proposal to topple most of the Affordable Care Act, according to a nonpartisan report that is likely to complicate GOP lawmakers’ efforts to unite around the plan.

headline: Intel Joins Silicon Valley’s Race to Make Best ‘Server on Wheels’
summary: Intel struck a deal to buy Mobileye for $15.3 billion, the latest investment by a technology company in the future of self-driving cars.

headline: Hemingway Was a Spy
summary: In 1940, as he was preparing to go on a trip to China, the writer agreed to work for the NKVD, the Soviet foreign intelligence agency. Harvey Klehr reviews “Writer, Sailor, Soldier, Spy” by Nicholas Reynolds.

headline: Trump Broadens CIA Powers, Allows Deadly Drone Strikes
summary: President Donald Trump has given the Central Intelligence Agency secret new authority to conduct drone strikes against suspected terrorists, U.S. officials said, changing the Obama administration’s policy of limiting the spy agency’s paramilitary role and reopening a turf war between the agency and the Pentagon.

headline: U.S. East Coast Braces for Late-Winter Blizzard
summary: A classic nor’easter is lashing the East Coast with snow and blizzard conditions Tuesday, bringing a late blast of winter to a region where residents only recently thought spring was in the air.

headline: Dow Drops as Investors Await Cues From Fed
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average and U.S. government-bond prices slipped as investors looked ahead to a key meeting of the Federal Reserve later this week.

summary: Ferraris that zoom to 211 mph. Royce-Royces with diamond-dusted paint. Dan Neil ponders the bubble economy as he tours the 2017 Geneva Auto Show.

headline: Mexico’s States Gained Power and Money; Then Came Corruption
summary: The sudden disappearance of a Mexican governor, leaving behind nearly empty state coffers, shows how the dispersal of political authority to the states made them vulnerable to graft.

summary: The yield topples its recent peak of 2.6% in mid-December and extends this month’s rise. Investors bet the Federal Reserve will raise rates later this week.

summary: As Saudi Arabia’s King Salman and his 1,000-plus entourage woo investors in Japan and China this week, they are facing a difficult task: convincing those countries, both big buyers of Saudi oil, that the kingdom is also a wise place to park their cash.

headline: Whitney Biennial 2017 Review: Aesthetics Are Alive Downtown

summary: To keep troops focused during a new NATO deployment, Army bans such on-base luxuries as Whoppers and lattes; ‘Spartan, plus Wi-Fi’

headline: Do Traders See Data Before Release? Markets Say Yes
summary: U.K. government-bond futures often move sharply in the 24 hours before sensitive economic reports, a phenomenon that suggests investors may be trading with knowledge of official statistics before they become public.

The design is part of a movement in the tech industry to develop software that can be creative and produce content such as songs, logos and artwork.

headline: GOP Health Plan Would Hit Rural Areas Hard
summary: The House Republican effort to overhaul the Affordable Care Act could hit many rural areas particularly hard, sharply increasing the cost for some residents buying their own insurance.

headline: Atticus Finch, Perry Mason and Michael Clayton Have Nothing on the Legal Profession’s Favorite Attorney: Vinny
summary: After 25 years, the 1992 comedy ‘My Cousin Vinny,’ with its smart-aleck hero played by Joe Pesci, is still a hit with lawyers; ‘a paean to the American system of justice’
